div.p: Greetings. I will do everything possible to show myself grateful to you all, to whom I now give the greatest thanks I can. Letters from England were written in December.
The matter of religion is in excellent condition.
May God confirm His word forever.

There is no mention of an agreement between the English and the Scots, nor do I think it is true that they conspired against the French. However, it is written about the Scots: they are progressing fearlessly in religion, the French fleet, which wanted to bring aid to the queen, was scattered by a storm and several ships were sunk.
No marriage yet for the Queen of England.
The envoy of the Emperor, who negotiated in the name of Charles, has departed.
The second son of the King of Sweden is still in England, who negotiated for his younger brother Eric; but it is believed he will achieve nothing. I will provide more shortly.
You will share this information with friends, especially with the most honorable gentleman, the envoy, to whom you will commend me.
The letters, which you write you have not yet received, I handed over to SÃ¼ler, who says he served your bishop. I included the letters of the envoy to you, as you yourself ordered.

They are also included for my Christoph. He says that Mr. Caspar von Salis has promised to sell the horse. I also kindly ask him, as my gracious young lord, to help ensure it is sold. For if you send it down to me, I know even less how to sell it.
You might think, if you sell it, that I might think I wanted to get more out of it here, etc. No, I have written before and say it again: sell it as you can and as if it were yours.

Whatever you get for it, I will be satisfied. But if it cannot be otherwise, you must send it to me; but it will not be worth it to me, because I know even less how to sell it and must also entrust it to other people; for I am not at all capable of the negotiations. Therefore, act as a good friend.
Farewell forever with all of ours.
To the most excellent Mr. Johannes Fabricius, most faithful minister of the Church of Chur, godfather and dearest brother. Chur.
